questions.question: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus?
Which of the following is a false statement regarding Cryptococcus neoformans?

options.B: It most commonly causes meningitis in AIDS patients
options.C: There are 3 serological types based on capsular polysaccharide
options.D: Niger seed agar is used to demonstrate melanin production

questions.explanation: Pathogenic varieties of cryptococcus including C. neoformans and C. gattii are laccase positive.They also have ability to grow at 37° C and these factors are used to differentiate them fromnon-pathogenic cryptococci.Cryptococci have been classified into 5 serotypes (A, B, C, D, and AD) based on their capsularpolysaccharide:• Three serotypes fall under Cryptococcus neoformans - A(var. grubii), D(var. neoformans), andAD(a hybrid of serotypes A and D). Although serotype AD is very similar to serotypes A and D, theisolates still comprise a discrete group that can be distinguished.• The serotypes B and C are now considered a different species - Cryptococcus gattii.Niger seed agar is a solid medium used for selective and differential isolationof Cryptococcus neoformans from clinical specimens. C. neoformans and C. gattii produces brown480colonies on this medium due to the formation of melanin. Melanin is produced by laccaseusing caffeic acid as the substrate.The following image shows pigmented colonies of C. gattii growing on niger seed agar.Cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, is an opportunistic infection seen inindividuals with AIDS. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of thiscondition.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms cannot be grown on any culture media?
questions.explanation: Rhinosporidium seeberi and Pneumocystis jirovecii are non-cultivable organisms and cannot begrown on any culture media.Another example of a non-cultivable fungus is Lacazia loboi. It causes Jorge Lobo's disease whichis a chronic subcutaneous mycosis.Rhizopus oryzae is a mold which is easily cultivable on SDA. Dimorphic fungi like Histoplasmacapsulatum and Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis are identified based on their colony morphology onSDA.Note: Recently, molecular biological techniques have demonstrated that Rhinosporidium isan aquatic protistan parasite. Infections due to Rhinosporidium have been classified underinfections due to Protozoa under the ICD 11.

questions.question: A patient with HIV presented complaining of cough and progressively worsening breathingdifficulty. Chest X-ray showed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The findings of microscopicexamination of his bronchoalveolar lavage is given below. Which is the most probablecausative organism?473
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture and the GMS stained smear showing the black-colored cystsresembling crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) caused byPneumocystis jirovecii.481Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. ChestX-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or with diffuse bilateral interstitialinfiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.Treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) and pentamidineisethionate. Cotrimoxazole can also be used for prophylaxis in patients having AIDS.The following X-ray image shows a cyst (arrow) and bilateral lung infiltrates in a patient with PCP:Pneumocystis jirovecii

questions.question: A middle-aged immunocompromised patient presents with complaints of pain duringswallowing. She describes it as a burning sensation that radiates to her back every time sheswallows. Oral examination reveals creamy white patches on the oral mucosa. The wet mountmicroscopy of the scraping obtained from the patches is given below. Identify the organism.474
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of odynophagia, creamy white patches on the oral mucosa and the wetmount microscopy showing budding yeasts with pseudohyphae are suggestive of oral candidiasiscaused by Candida albicans.482It is an opportunistic infection commonly seen in immunocompromised states like AIDS, diabetesetc.Treatment includes topical azoles or nystatin.

questions.explanation: The image shows the germ tube test used for identifying Candida albicans.Unlike other species of candida, yeast cells of Candida albicans will begin to form germ tubes afterincubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as theReynolds-Braude phenomenon. This test is positive for Candia dubliniensis as well.

questions.question: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown inthe image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is thelikely diagnosis?475
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue,lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causativeagent is usually Candida albicans.It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellularimmunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. Itis commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over theflexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear aslacy, white, and raised lesions.Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering thetonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.question: Galactomannan in serum is seen in:
questions.explanation: The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive (deep-seated) mycoses caused byAspergillus species.Galactomannan is a component of the cell wall of Aspergillus. It can be detected in serum orbronchoalveolar lavage by ELISA for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children.This test is especially useful in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients or patients withhematologic malignancies.Other diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis are:• A positive culture from the affected organ483• Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan• Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 450 and conidiophores.• Halo sign on CT scan

questions.question: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain.476
questions.explanation: The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (450) uniform, branching septate hyphaewhich is suggestive of Aspergillus species.Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear characteristic conidialstructures. Long aseptate conidiophores are seen with terminal vesicles on which phialides arearranged in basipetal chains.The following image shows the lactophenol cotton blue solution (LPCB) mount of Aspergillusfumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles.Option A: Mucor produces nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in asporangium.Option B: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-likeconidiophores.Option D: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising ingroups directly above the rhizoids.

questions.question: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage fortwo years. She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polypswith mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissuebiopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the followingappearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?477529
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture and the microscopic appearance is suggestive of fungal rhinosinusitis.The most probable causative organism is Aspergillus fumigatus. It is commonly involved inparanasal sinus mycoses (fungal sinusitis).484The disease has been described to have four types:•allergic•⚫ non-invasive⚫ invasive••fulminantA possible fifth type called non-invasive destructive type may also exist.Zygomycetes like mucor and rhizopus are the common agents in fulminant type of fungalsinusitis.The characteristic microscopic appearance of Aspergillus fumigatus:• The vesicle is conical.•Phialides are arranged in a single row.•Conidia arise from the upper third of the vesicle and are hyaline.Option B: Aspergillus flavus appears as follows:• The vesicle is globular.•Phialides are arranged in one or two rows.•Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.Option C: Aspergillus niger appear as follows:485C• The vesicle is globular shaped.•Phialides are in two rows.10um• Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black.Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum appear as follows:1000010um•Septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores (brush or broomappearance).

questions.question: What is the drug of choice for invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.explanation: Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. It canalso be used against candida species (including glabrata and krusei), scedosporium and fusarium.486The other options can be used as alternatives for the treatment of invasive pulmonaryaspergillosis if voriconazole is unavailable.

questions.question: ẞ 1-3 glucan assay is used to diagnose all except?
questions.explanation: The ẞ 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used to diagnose mucormycosis. This condition is usuallydiagnosed based on clinical features and culture.The test detects the presence of (1-3)-ẞ-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wallpolysaccharide found in most fungi.It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan byusing purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of≥80 pg/mL is considered a positive result.Fungi that do not contain BDG in their cell walls include•Cryptococcus neoformans•Zygomycetes like rhizopus and mucor• Blastomyces dermatitidisMucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis caused by zygomycetes, which do not contain(1-3)-ß-d-glucan, and hence, the ẞ 1-3 glucan assay cannot be used for its diagnosis.

questions.question: Which fungus is most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabeticketoacidosis ?
questions.explanation: Rhizopus is the most common fungus associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabeticketoacidosis.Diabetic patients are immunocompromised and so prone to develop opportunistic infections.Orbital cellulitis with Rhizopus may turn fatal in these patients as it is an angioinvasive fungusand could lead to septicemia and thromboses.

questions.question: 478A 68-year-old post-COVID-19 patient presented with a black, foul-smelling nasal dischargeand blurred vision. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass eroding the septum and hardpalate was visualised. Lactophenol cotton blue mount from the culture is given below. Whichof the following statements is false regarding the condition?8%800900880

options.B: Iron administration to patients with active infection should be avoided
options.C: Posaconazole can be used to treat it
options.D: Pulmonary form is the most common

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the LPCB mount showing aseptate hyphae branching atright-angles is strongly suggestive of mucormycosis. Rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis is themost common form of mucormycosis. Pulmonary mucormycosis is the second most commonform.Mucormycosis is an invasive disease caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor,and Lichtheimia. The disease is often characterized by hyphae growing in and around the bloodvessels. It can turn fatal on cerebral involvement and development of speticemia.Risk factors for the infection include:•Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).487• Elevated levels of free iron.• Defects in phagocytic function.•• Organ or hematopoietic stem transplantation.Treatment of choice is Amphotericin-B. Posaconazole can be used as an alternative drug.488
